parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Math

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Remainder of a divided by b.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> [[Number]] <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> a '''mod''' b

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> a: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> b: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]]
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <br><code>_rem <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> 3 [[mod]] 2;</code>
Result is 1

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[Math Commands]], [[Operators]], [[a % b]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on 01:34, 16 April 2006</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Hoz|Hoz]]<dd class="note">
* Remainder is calculated in real domain.
* mod is identical to [[a % b]]
You can use mod to round a decimal number down to the nearest whole number. For example: If you wanted to use the command random to generate a whole number between 0 and 5, you could put this in a script: 
<code>_rand = [[random]] 6;
_num <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> _rand - (_rand [[mod]] 1);
</code>
In A1, the new commands [[round]], [[floor]] or [[ceil]] would be the easier way to round.
<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
